character_1_text.eng: Wow, this book looks interesting! Can you see the picture? The tiger is smiling. Why do you think he is smiling?

character_3_text.eng: Thatâ€™s right, it's a balloon, what colour is it?

rows.character_3_text: Thatâ€™s right, it's a balloon, what colour is it?

rows.text_1_facilitator: 5ï¸âƒ£ Here are five ways to prepare your child for learning how to read when they are older. The activities all focus on reading books together ğŸ’™

text_1_facilitator.eng: 5ï¸âƒ£ Here are five ways to prepare your child for learning how to read when they are older. The activities all focus on reading books together ğŸ’™

section_1_text.eng:
ğŸ’¡ Books with no words help with imagination, ideas, and learning new words. Together, name and describe what is in the pictures. Try to communicate in a way that your child can understand. 
â­ Books with words help to understand letters and sounds!
ğŸµ Focus on words that rhyme, repeat, and start with the same letter, like â€œbig black boot.â€

section_2_text.eng:
ğŸ“– You can share books with your child anywhere- in the living room or bedroom, for example! 
Get rid of any distractions (like the TV ğŸ“ºâŒ). 
â° Pick a time every day when you can share books with your child. 
ğŸ’¡ If your child wants to, let them choose a book ğŸ˜ƒ

section_3_text.eng:
ğŸ‘€ From the book cover, ask your child what they think the story might be about. 
â¡ï¸ Throughout the book, ask your child who, what, where, when, why, and how questions.
âœ¨ When your child doesnâ€™t know the name of the object you pointed at, point at it and say what it is. This will help your child learn new words.
â˜€ï¸ If you have read a story many times, see if your child knows what comes next! 
ğŸ‘€ Describe whatâ€™s happening in a picture.

section_4_text.eng:
ğŸ‘€ Notice what your child is interested in and talk about it. Help them understand the story and character emotions. ğŸ’š
ğŸˆ Explore their responses by rephrasing or adding more information - help your child learn new words and understand more ğŸ˜ƒ
ğŸ’™ When your child talks about the book or answers your questions about the book, respond positively and encourage them, even if they are wrong.
ğŸ‘‚ Ask your child to repeat what you have taught them.

section_5_text.eng: ğŸŒ· Always connect whatâ€™s in the book to your childâ€™s experience.
